title: Literature Review: Numerical Integration Methods for ODEs
summary: Review of four key numerical integration methods applicable to the pendulum ODE, with pros/cons for Hamiltonian systems.

methods.name: Forward Euler
cons: Requires very small dt for accuracy
methods.energy_behavior: Systematic energy growth (gain) for Hamiltonian systems - secular drift

methods.name: 4th-order Runge-Kutta (RK4)
pros: Best accuracy-to-cost ratio for general ODEs
Good stability properties for non-stiff problems
cons: Not symplectic - energy drifts over very long times
methods.energy_behavior: Slow energy drift; much better than Euler but unbounded over infinite time

methods.name: Stormer-Verlet (Leapfrog)
pros: Energy oscillates but does NOT drift secularly
Only 1 force evaluation per step (same cost as Euler)
Excellent for long-time integration of Hamiltonian systems
cons: Not suitable for non-separable Hamiltonians without modification
Variable step sizes can destroy symplecticity
methods.energy_behavior: Bounded energy oscillation around true energy - no secular drift. Preserves a shadow Hamiltonian H_tilde = H + O(h^2).

methods.name: Symplectic Euler (Semi-implicit Euler)
methods.formula: p_{n+1} = p_n - h*dH/dq(q_n); q_{n+1} = q_n + h*dH/dp(p_{n+1})
cons: Less accurate than Verlet for same step size
methods.energy_behavior: Bounded energy oscillation, larger amplitude than Verlet

key_references.title: Geometric Numerical Integration: Structure-Preserving Algorithms for Ordinary Differential Equations
key_references.author: Hairer, Lubich, Wanner
key_references.note: Definitive textbook on symplectic and geometric integrators

recommendation: Use Euler as baseline, RK4 for high-accuracy short-time simulations, and Stormer-Verlet for long-time energy-conserving simulations.
